When it comes to feminism and the "struggle" that women had to go through in order to have equal rights with men...for some reasons (convenience most likely) usually leaves out the struggle that men also had to go through to have equal rights as the land owners.
In other terms, men had to go into war and literaly put their life at stake in an armed conflict to achieve rights to vote.
Women did organise, dress up real nice and walk out onto the streets with pamphlets.
I am not dwarfing the historical struggle of women - by no means at all! If anything,
all I am doing is pointing out at the broader context of the struggle that most people creating this onesided form of sexist narrative conveniently overlook. The real struggle (against the owners of land and powers fighting one another...a war of supremacy which was the state of affairs on our planet amongst members of our species..and it seemingly never went away ) People who just start blabbing that all men oppressed all women and enslaved all slaves...and the one to blame is a white male (any and all)...there are plenty of those people having that twisted narrow onesided argument.
And from what I can tell there is even something of a movement of energised individuals with that onesided simplified narrative...which is only asking for troublesome real world implications.

Modern Life: Crash Course European Histo.comment_text: Merriam-Webster defines 'modern' as "of, relating to, or characteristic of the present or the immediate past." There is no positive or negative connotation, nor any way for people to be excluded or included except by the time period they lived in. People who, in their own individual minds, load such a neutral term are easily manipulated by it.

I don't know that it's possible for us to disentangle what's happening NOW in a way that would be so objective as to allow an honest comparison. We can try and we might even get close, but I feel like we're too much in the middle of everything to really get the clearest perspective.


That said - the Internet in and of itself is a huge thing that marks this era as "modern" to me. And who is excluded by the Internet? Well, only those without access, and you won't hear much from them, will you? I'm fortunate to be able to get internet even though my family is very, very poor, and trust me I really do know how fortunate. Without that benefit of internet in my home, I would have to, at best, walk several miles to reach a location with internet-connected computers. (Obviously, being poor, just going somewhere with free WiFi does me no good: I have no device capable of connecting.) And yet so many folks take that connection, and the devices that enable such connection and communication, for granted. "What do you mean you don't have a phone?" And nowadays that doesn't mean "I have no phone in my house," it means for those folks at least, "I don't have a smart phone."


Access to technology like this, access to communities, access to information, is a huge wall between social and economic classes now. We're still wading through the changes and the shifts in attitudes - social and otherwise - and there's no way to really know which way that journey is going to go in another ten years. We can hope for the best, and the very existence of those hopes makes this transition scary as hell. There's a lot at stake potentially. We could become more inclusive of all humans than we've ever been, we could really and truly become a global community for the first time ever. Or we could use this against ourselves and erase entire continents of people from our day-to-day existence. We've done that before, too.


For myself, I try to hold onto the faith that people want the best outcome for not just themselves but others; that we can and will take a view that builds the longer table, instead of the higher wall.

Hmmm.  Isn't modern a purely "technical" term, not a political or value judgment?  Doesn't it mean nothing more than "the current time"?  Isn't everyone, always, living in what, for them, are modern times?  It might be that some societies which value timelessness -- that emphasize stability over change -- have no concept of modernity.  Modernity implies change, that the current age is distinguishable from past ages -- that "ages" or "eras" exist.  A society that wanted to think of itself as part of an eternal classical golden age might find "modern" meaningless.  But for us, I think the question is always "how far back does 'modern' extend?"  It extends back as far as seems to be our own era, our own age, a time we recognize, a time we feel we could live in without feeling we were in a historical role play.  I don't think it's a value judgment (modern times when we are no longer barbarians) so much as a comparison (modern times when things have been about like they are now).  For me, I think it's about World War One.  Before that, horses and carriages, men in top hats as everyday wear, gas lighting, telegrams.  After that, autos, telephones, electricity, movies, sound recordings.  I think the Age of Invention -- specifically consumer-good invention -- defines modernity for most of us.  Politically or philosophically it's much slipperier.  The rise of democracy?  The recognition of universal human rights?  No, modern times also saw the rise of dictatorship and oppression.  The best that could be said is that many of us ASPIRE to a more small-l liberal political philosophy, yet even that may go too far (as current nationalism in a West that liked to think of itself as liberal points out).  So modernity may be more simply a matter of available consumer technology than anything else.  But that may be nonsense; this is not a strongly-held opinion.

Great series, but I cannot help feel this series too heavily focuses on the role/status of women, racism and oppression as if European history was mostly defined by these. Undoubtedly they are important and should not be downplayed (as it is often done in history books) but a video called Modern Life mentions science, education and art in 2 minutes and goes on to talk about the status of women in the next 12. Modern, historiographically, has been a term used to further imperialism. Europe and its settler colonial offspring are "modern" and "rational" whereas the rest of the world is "backwards" and "traditional". This justified colonialism for centuries and continues to justify informal empire today (check out the contrasting narratives surrounding Ahed Tamimi and Malala Yousafzai, for example). It should be understood in the context of a foucauldian discourse– that is to say in terms of the way assigning meanings to things advances, conceals, or creates power.
That said, John et al. are exactly right that public schools are a central part of modernity– public schools represent the most direct infusion of White supremacist, capitalist, cisheteropatriarchal propaganda into our society, so much so that it has even been used directly as a tool of genocide (look up the "boarding schools" to which Indigenous children were subjected in the US).

a person is trapped by their times, in terms of thinking, what context of thought they can draw on to express any idea, that the last point seems to cover what is modern. the habit of people to live within their times without a means to think outside of them in any real way. a person can only look back and support the value of their time alive through recasting the past or future as good or bad, or along a line of progression accordingly. but there is no reference, improvements of some systems may or may not connote progress, it is difficult within a time to tell. and a person in any time is at an apex of their society, and can only imagine the future or past in answer to their hopes and discontents. so to me modern is the time in which the person referencing the term is living. a bit weak, but it seems so.

The older woman at centre-left of the frame at 10:05 is my great-great-grandaunt Frigga Carlberg (1851-1925). She was an early liberal politician in Gothenburg, Sweden, and an influential voice for the cause of women’s suffrage. Sweden finally gave women the right to vote in 1919, and Frigga got to vote once before her death in the general election of 1921.

This video was not a good reflection of the time it depicted. It was however a very good depiction of the time we live in. Universal suffrage for women was only a decade or two behind universal suffrage for men in most European countries. In eastern Europe no one had the chance to vote in democratic elections before the 1990s. I get it. Most women didn't have the same political rights as most men for a period of time. The vast majority of men did not have the same political rights as some men for almost the entirety of European history. It's difficult to say who had it worse in the good old days. Women died in childbirth, men died on the battlefields, in the mines or at sea. The defining characteristics of the times were the scientific advances, the building of democratic institutions and the building of an international community. It is strange to use the entire fourteen minutes of the narrative on only one of many defining characteristics of the time.

I don't see how Pierre Currie being dead for 5 years before Marie Currie won her second Nobel Prize is evidence against the claim that her husband did most of the work. Most Nobel Prizes are awarded for work that was done decades earlier, and the prize cannot be given to anyone posthumously so awarding his wife/research partner would have seemed a natural way to award him. None of this of course means she did not deserve it for work on her own, it just is not great evidence for the claim.
